content:
Can someone try to give me a very concrete example? I've read the nLab page, Lawvere's Toward the Description in a Smooth Topos of the Dynamically Possible Motions and Deformations of a Continuous Body and attempted a few others, all of which presented things in increasingly general ways, without giving concrete examples. (There were plenty of highly abstract examples.)

I don't mind working out details, but I need a concrete starting point. [Hint: anything start with 'topos' will fail the ELI5 criteria; if you use the word 'presheaf' you're probably thinking at too high a level still, and need to expand things out. Please.]
What is ELI5?
Ah, "explain it like I'm 5". I assumed it was some categorical axiom heh.
I know the interval (1-cube) in the category of cartesian cubical sets is supposed to be an example, though I never worked it out for myself. (I didn't say "presheaf"...)
I'm surprised it's not on the nLab page for amazing right adjoint already.

Once someone figures out an example, I can stick it on the nLab. I think Lawvere's favorite examples involve "infinitesimal spaces", - maybe like the "walking tangent vector" space in synthetic differential geometry?
I get the idea of that "walking tangent vector" or "infinitesimal arrow" pretty well, but I haven't thought about this "amazing right adjoint".

So this fails the ELI5 test, but here goes. Say CCC is a category with an object III (for "interval") such that CCC has all products X×IX \times IX×I for X∈CX \in CX∈C. The exponential −yI{-}^{yI}−yI on C^=SetCop\hat C = \mathrm{Set}^{C^{\mathrm{op}}}C^=SetCop has left adjoint −×yI{-} \times yI−×yI (here yyy is the Yoneda embedding). But yX×yI≅y(X×I)yX \times yI \cong y(X \times I)yX×yI≅y(X×I), so −×yI{-} \times yI−×yI takes representables to representables and as a left adjoint, it must be the left Kan extension along the functor −×I{-} \times I−×I on CCC. That means that −yI{-}^{yI}−yI is the restriction along this functor and so it has a right adjoint, given by right Kan extension along the same functor.

It's a shame you ruled out presheaves, because they provide the easiest example in my opinion, thanks to Proposition 2.5 of the nLab page.

Let C\mathcal{C}C be a small category, and consider the category of functors E:=[C,Set]\mathcal{E}:= [\mathcal{C},\mathrm{Set}]E:=[C,Set]; this is the category of "copresheaves on C\mathcal{C}C", but the essential thing is that the objects of E\mathcal{E}E are functors and the morphisms are natural transformations. For any object FFF in this category, we can consider the representable functor HomE(F,−)\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathcal{E}}(F,-)HomE​(F,−) to sets, which always has a left adjoint given by sending any set AAA to an AAA-indexed coproduct of copies of FFF. On the other hand, this representable functor has a right adjoint if and only if it is a (retract of a) representable copresheaf the latter being a functor of the form HomC(C,−)\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathcal{C}}(C,-)HomC​(C,−) for some object CCC of C\mathcal{C}C.

The objects whose representable functors admit right adjoints are called "tiny objects", so the above says that we can identify the representable copresheaves on a category up to retracts as the subcategory of tiny objects.

I don't think he ruled out examples that happen to be presheaves. I think he just wanted a concrete example, not a general example of the sort you just gave. So please give an example of your example!

The category of directed graphs is the category of copresheaves on the double-arrow category s,t:E⇉Vs,t: E \rightrightarrows Vs,t:E⇉V. By the above, the tiny objects are the digraph consisting of a single vertex and no edges, and the graph consisting of two vertices and a single edge from one to the other. I think this is a very instructive example to work out the details of!
(Note that this is normally presented as the category of presheaves on the double arrow category, but the result is identical; for the purposes of understanding this concept, it doesn't matter.)

Aha, that last example is indeed something I can sink my teeth in to. Thank you.

And indeed, I want to work my way up to understanding why this has anything to do with "infinitesimals". But I would like to do it via seeing 'tiny' objects in a number of sufficiently different concrete settings first.

Morgan Rogers (he/him) said:

The category of directed graphs is the category of copresheaves on the double-arrow category s,t:E⇉Vs,t: E \rightrightarrows Vs,t:E⇉V. By the above, the tiny objects are the digraph consisting of a single vertex and no edges, and the graph consisting of two vertices and a single edge from one to the other. I think this is a very instructive example to work out the details of!

There is some problem with the terminology. On the nlab there are two things that are called tiny:

  • externally tiny: objects XXX in E\mathcal{E}E such that HomE(X,−)\mathrm{Hom}_\mathcal{E}(X,-)HomE​(X,−) preserves colimits.
  • internally tiny: objects XXX in E\mathcal{E}E such that Y↦YXY \mapsto Y^XY↦YX preserves colimits.

I don't know whether the two graphs that you mention are also internally tiny (I'll try to compute the exponentials).

The graph yV\mathbf{y}VyV with a single vertex and no edges is the terminal object, so then the functor Y↦YyVY \mapsto Y^{\mathbf{y}V}Y↦YyV is the identity functor (which does preserve colimits). So this graph should be internally tiny as well. (The graph with a single vertex and no edges is not the terminal object, so this argument is wrong.)

But if yE\mathbf{y}EyE is the graph with two vertices and an edge connecting them, then I believe (yE)yE(\mathbf{y}E)^{\mathbf{y}E}(yE)yE has 4 edges, while (yE⊔yE)yE(\mathbf{y}E \sqcup \mathbf{y}E)^{\mathbf{y}E}(yE⊔yE)yE has 32 edges... so Y↦YyEY \mapsto Y^{\mathbf{y}E}Y↦YyE does not preserve coproducts in this case.

Jens Hemelaer said:

But if yE\mathbf{y}EyE is the graph with two vertices and an edge connecting them, then I believe (yE)yE(\mathbf{y}E)^{\mathbf{y}E}(yE)yE has 4 edges...

I'm having trouble seeing 4 edges. What are these 4 edges? For starters, what are the vertices of (yE)yE(\mathbf{y}E)^{\mathbf{y}E}(yE)yE?

A vertex of (yE)yE(\mathbf{y}E)^{\mathbf{y}E}(yE)yE corresponds to a morphism f:yE→yEf: \mathbf{y}E \to \mathbf{y}Ef:yE→yE, right? And a morphism from yE\mathbf{y}EyE to itself must map the one edge of this graph to itself. So I'm getting just one vertex.

Similarly, the set of edges corresponds to morphisms yE×yE→yEyE\times yE\to yEyE×yE→yE. The product has one edge (0,0)→(1,1)(0,0)\to(1,1)(0,0)→(1,1) and two isolated points (1,0)(1,0)(1,0) and (0,1)(0,1)(0,1). The diagonal edge has to map to the only edge in yEyEyE, but the isolated points can go to either vertex, making 4 options.

Ok, I miscalculated with the vertices...
A vertex of (yE)yE(\mathbf{y}E)^{\mathbf{y}E}(yE)yE is the same thing as a morphism yV×yE→yE\mathbf{y}V \times \mathbf{y}E \to \mathbf{y}EyV×yE→yE. Here, yV×yE\mathbf{y}V \times \mathbf{y}EyV×yE is the graph with two vertices and no edges. So there are 4 morphisms yV×yE→yE\mathbf{y}V \times \mathbf{y}E \to \mathbf{y}EyV×yE→yE which means that (yE)yE(\mathbf{y}E)^{\mathbf{y}E}(yE)yE has four vertices.

I made a similar mistake when I said that the functor Y↦YyVY \mapsto Y^{\mathbf{y}V}Y↦YyV is the identity functor.
You can compute that the functor Y↦YyVY \mapsto Y^{\mathbf{y}V}Y↦YyV sends a graph to the complete directed graph on its vertices.
This functor does not preserve colimits (not even coproducts), so yV\mathbf{y}VyV is not an internally tiny object.

Here are the directed graphs (yE)yE(\mathbf{y}E)^{\mathbf{y}E}(yE)yE and (yE⊔yE)yE(\mathbf{y}E \sqcup \mathbf{y}E)^{\mathbf{y}E}(yE⊔yE)yE (hopefully no miscalculations). The loops are not shown in the pictures, the first should have a loop at vertex "st", and the second should have a loop at vertices 1 and 11. exponential1.png exponential2.png

In general, exponentials in a presheaf category are hard to compute... so it is difficult to come up with an easy and interesting example where taking exponentials has a right adjoint (the amazing right adjoint).
I bet you're used to reflexive graphs, Jens. For reflexive graphs I believe Y↦YyVY \mapsto Y^{\mathbf{y}{V}}Y↦YyV is the identity functor, and other things change too.
Yes I agree. I still think it is a bit surprising intuitively that the product of a point and an edge is two points...
This whole discussion is a splendid illustration of why I wanted explicit examples!

Jacques Carette said:

This whole discussion is a splendid illustration of why I wanted explicit examples!

Yes exactly... Here is the easiest example that I could come up with. Let E\mathcal{E}E be the category that has as objects the triples (f,A,B)(f,A,B)(f,A,B) where AAA and BBB are sets and f:A→Bf : A \to Bf:A→B is a function. We look at the object j:∅→{∗}j : \varnothing \to \{\ast\}j:∅→{∗} in E\mathcal{E}E. For this object, you can compute that the functor X↦XjX \mapsto X^jX↦Xj is given as follows: if f:A→Bf : A \to Bf:A→B is an object of E\mathcal{E}E, then fjf^jfj is the identity map B→BB \to BB→B. This exponential functor has a right adjoint (the amazing right adjoint), which sends an object g:C→Dg : C \to Dg:C→D in E\mathcal{E}E to the identity function C→CC \to CC→C.

Some theoretical background (using the terminology and results from the nlab page here): E\mathcal{E}E is the topos of presheaves on the category C\mathcal{C}C with two objects and precisely one non-identity morphism (from one object to the other). Because E=PSh(C)\mathcal{E}=\mathbf{PSh}(\mathcal{C})E=PSh(C) is a sheaf topos, the exponential (−)j(-)^j(−)j has a right adjoint if and only if it preserves colimits, so if and only if jjj is internally tiny. Further, because C\mathcal{C}C is a category admitting finite products, the internally tiny and externally tiny objects in E\mathcal{E}E agree (Proposition 2.4). Now from Example 2.2 it follows that jjj is tiny, because it is a representable presheaf. Conversely, you can use Theorem 2.14 here to show that jjj and the terminal object are the only tiny objects in E\mathcal{E}E.
Very nice explanation! Presheaves on this particular category C\mathcal{C}C are like graphs, only simpler. I sometimes think of them as graphs where every edge has a source but no target.
It's cool that C\mathcal{C}C has finite products. One object is terminal, and the product of the other object with itself is itself.
One way to think about this is that C\mathcal{C}C is a poset, and a poset has finite products if every pair of objects has a greatest lower bound.
Viewed as a poset C\mathcal{C}C is an ordinal, the ordinal called "2", and any ordinal has finite products.

Here's a very simple example, the "cartesian cubical sets" that @Reid Barton already mentioned. Let BBB be the category of finite , strictly bipointed sets and C=BopC = B^{op}C=Bop the cartesian cube category - which is the free finite product category on an interval 1⇉I1 \rightrightarrows I1⇉I. Write the objects in the form [n][n][n], so I=[1]I = [1]I=[1] and [n]×[m]=[n+m][n] \times [m] = [n+m][n]×[m]=[n+m]. Presheaves on CCC are called (Cartesian) cubical sets, written cSetcSetcSet. There is a functor S:C→CS : C \to CS:C→C taking [n][n][n] to [n+1][n+1][n+1] , which induces S∗:cSet→cSetS^* : cSet \to cSetS∗:cSet→cSet by restriction, and therefore has both left S!S_!S!​ and right S∗S_*S∗​ adjoints. One can easily calculate that

S!X=X×IS!X = X\times IS!X=X×I

so its adjoint must be

S∗X=XIS^*X = X^IS∗X=XI.

The further right adjoint S∗S_*S∗​ then also exists and is therefore an "amazing right adjoint" XI⊣S∗XX^I \dashv S_*XXI⊣S∗​X. We write it as XIX_IXI​ and call it the "IthI^{th}Ith root". In particular, III itself is therefore "tiny".
this is essentially the same as Reid's example.
Can one exhibit / compute that further right adjoint? What does that functor actually do?

in cubical sets:
XI(n)=[In,XI]=[(In)I,X]=[(II)n,X]=[(I+1)n,X] X^I (n) = [ I^n , X_I ] = [ (I^n)^I , X ] = [ (I^I)^n, X ] = [(I + 1)^n, X]XI(n)=[In,XI​]=[(In)I,X]=[(II)n,X]=[(I+1)n,X]
=[Σk=0,...,nC(n,k)Ik,X] = [ \Sigma_{k=0, ..., n}C(n,k) I^{k} , X ] =[Σk=0,...,n​C(n,k)Ik,X]
=Πk=0,...,n[Ik,X]C(n,k) = \Pi_{k=0, ..., n}[ I^{k} , X ]^{C(n,k)} =Πk=0,...,n​[Ik,X]C(n,k)
=Πk=0,...,nX(k)C(n,k) = \Pi_{k=0, ..., n}X(k)^{C(n,k)}=Πk=0,...,n​X(k)C(n,k),
where C(n,k)C(n,k)C(n,k) is the binomial coefficient.
I think I can reconstruct all the justifications, except for [Ik,X]\left[I^k,X\right][Ik,X] to X(n)X(n)X(n). [I'm probably missing something simple, yet I am missing it!]
It would make more sense if it were X(k)X(k)X(k), but even then, I'm not sure.

Indeed, it should be [Ik,X]=X(k)[I^k, X] = X(k)[Ik,X]=X(k). Then [Ik,X]=X(k)[I^k, X] = X(k)[Ik,X]=X(k) is an application of Yoneda lemma to the category of presheaves
cSet≃PSh(C).cSet \simeq \mathbf{PSh}(C).cSet≃PSh(C).
We have Ik=y([k])I^k = \mathbf{y}([k])Ik=y([k]) where y\mathbf{y}y is the Yoneda embedding.

Aha, Yoneda, of course! Now, the above computation exhibits XIX^IXI quite explicitly, and XIX_IXI​ shows up in there as well -- but I was kind of hoping for XIX_IXI​ to be the item being isolated, not XIX^IXI. Or maybe it's just a typo and the very first thing should be XI(n)X_I(n)XI​(n) ?

Jacques Carette said:

It would make more sense if it were X(k)X(k)X(k), but even then, I'm not sure.

thanks - that was indeed a typo!
